elements.content: Humidity-induced multiple-step single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformations are observed in the cobalt phosphonate (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)­(H2O)2] (1), where bamdpH4 is (benzylazanediyl)­bis­(methylene)­diphosphonic acid, [C6H5CH2N­(CH2PO3H2)2]. Under high-humidity conditions (95% RH), compound 1 experiences hydrolysis at 60 °C which is accompanied by the transformation from a double-chain structure of compound 1 into a single-chain structure of [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·2H2O (2). When the humidity is below 10% RH, part of the lattice water in compound 2 can be released, forming a third phase, [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·H2O (3). The structural transformation processes have been monitored by infrared and proton conductivity measurements.
elements.clean_text: Humidity-induced multiple-step single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformations are observed in the cobalt phosphonate (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1), where bamdpH4 is (benzylazanediyl)bis(methylene)diphosphonic acid, [C6H5CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2]. Under high-humidity conditions (95% RH), compound 1 experiences hydrolysis at 60 °C which is accompanied by the transformation from a double-chain structure of compound 1 into a single-chain structure of [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2). When the humidity is below 10% RH, part of the lattice water in compound 2 can be released, forming a third phase, [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (3). The structural transformation processes have been monitored by infrared and proton conductivity measurements.

elements.content: The cobalt phosphonate (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)­(H2O)2] (1; bamdpH4 = C6H5CH2N­(CH2PO3H2)2) experiences a humidity-induced single-crystal to single-crystal structural transformation to form [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·2H2O (2), accompanied by a complete hydrolysis of the formate linkage.
elements.clean_text: The cobalt phosphonate (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1; bamdpH4 = C6H5CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) experiences a humidity-induced single-crystal to single-crystal structural transformation to form [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2), accompanied by a complete hydrolysis of the formate linkage.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted intense current interest owing to their potential applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensing, magnetism, proton conduction, etc. Of particular interest are those showing solid-state phase transitions triggered by external stimuli, which is often accompanied by a distinct change in functions. A single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation can provide a precise visualization about the structural changes during the phase transitions, and hence a structure–property relationship can be well illustrated. So far, a number of MOFs or CPs have been reported to experience SC-SC transformations induced by heat, light, redox, chemical reactions, and guest exchange. In contrast, humidity-induced SC-SC transformations have rarely been described.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted intense current interest owing to their potential applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensing, magnetism, proton conduction, etc. Of particular interest are those showing solid-state phase transitions triggered by external stimuli, which is often accompanied by a distinct change in functions. A single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation can provide a precise visualization about the structural changes during the phase transitions, and hence a structure-property relationship can be well illustrated. So far, a number of MOFs or CPs have been reported to experience SC-SC transformations induced by heat, light, redox, chemical reactions, and guest exchange. In contrast, humidity-induced SC-SC transformations have rarely been described.

elements.content: Metal phosphonates, as an important class of organic–inorganic hybrid materials, have received increasing attention recently due to their significance in the fields of catalysis, ion exchange, magnetism, and proton conductivity. Although solid-state phase transitions have been reported in metal phosphonate systems together with drastic changes in their physical and chemical properties, those showing SC-SC transformations are extremely rare. Albrecht-Schmitt and co-workers reported a few nanotubular uranyl phosphonates which can exchange ions in a SC-SC manner in solution. Reversible SC-SC transformations were also observed in the cobalt phosphonates Co2(pbtcH)­(2,2′-bpy)2(H2O) and Co2(pbtcH) (phen)2(H2O) (pbtcH5 = 5-phosphonatophenyl-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid) upon dehydration and rehydration, which involve the breakage and reconstruction of covalent bonds. More recently, we found that the number of lattice waters in a Co–Ca phosphonate can be controlled by humidity, resulting in a remarkable change in the proton conductivity of the material.
elements.clean_text: Metal phosphonates, as an important class of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, have received increasing attention recently due to their significance in the fields of catalysis, ion exchange, magnetism, and proton conductivity. Although solid-state phase transitions have been reported in metal phosphonate systems together with drastic changes in their physical and chemical properties, those showing SC-SC transformations are extremely rare. Albrecht-Schmitt and co-workers reported a few nanotubular uranyl phosphonates which can exchange ions in a SC-SC manner in solution. Reversible SC-SC transformations were also observed in the cobalt phosphonates Co2(pbtcH)(2,2'-bpy)2(H2O) and Co2(pbtcH) (phen)2(H2O) (pbtcH5 = 5-phosphonatophenyl-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid) upon dehydration and rehydration, which involve the breakage and reconstruction of covalent bonds. More recently, we found that the number of lattice waters in a Co-Ca phosphonate can be controlled by humidity, resulting in a remarkable change in the proton conductivity of the material.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the new double-chain CoII phosphonate (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)­(H2O)2] (1), where bamdpH4 is (benzylazanediyl)­bis­(methylene)­diphosphonic acid (C6H5CH2N­(CH2PO3H2)2). It experiences a SC-SC structural transformation at 60 °C and 95% relative humidity (RH), forming the single-chain compound [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·2H2O (2). The humidity-induced SC-SC transformation of compound 1 is unusual, because the process involves the hydrolysis of a bridging ligand of HCOO–, unlike the aforementioned Co–Ca phosphonate, which involves only the change of lattice water. The process can be monitored by infrared (IR) spectra and proton conductivity measurements. Furthermore, compound 2 can also undergo a SC-SC transformation below 10% RH, leading to a third phase, [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·H2O (3).
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report the new double-chain CoII phosphonate (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1), where bamdpH4 is (benzylazanediyl)bis(methylene)diphosphonic acid (C6H5CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2). It experiences a SC-SC structural transformation at 60 °C and 95% relative humidity (RH), forming the single-chain compound [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2). The humidity-induced SC-SC transformation of compound 1 is unusual, because the process involves the hydrolysis of a bridging ligand of HCOO-, unlike the aforementioned Co-Ca phosphonate, which involves only the change of lattice water. The process can be monitored by infrared (IR) spectra and proton conductivity measurements. Furthermore, compound 2 can also undergo a SC-SC transformation below 10% RH, leading to a third phase, [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (3).

elements.content: The reagents and solvents employed were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. (Benzylazanediyl)­bis­(methylene)­diphosphonic acid (bamdpH4) was prepared according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on an Elementar Vario MICRO elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Bruker TENSOR 27 IR spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 STARe instrument in the range of 30–500 °C under a nitrogen flow at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE XRD instrument using Cu Kα radiation. The UV–vis spectra were measured on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV/vis/NIR spectrometer. Mass spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu GC-MS QP2010 plus instrument. The humid environment was controlled by an Espec Corp. SH-221 humidity control oven. The impedance measurements were carried out under multiple different environmental conditions by the conventional quasi-four-probe method, using gold paste and gold wires (50 μm diameter) with a Solartron SI 1260 Impedance/Gain-Phase Analyzer and 1296 Dielectric Interface in the frequency range of 1 MHz to 0.1 Hz.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The reagents and solvents employed were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. (Benzylazanediyl)bis(methylene)diphosphonic acid (bamdpH4) was prepared according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on an Elementar Vario MICRO elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Bruker TENSOR 27 IR spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 STARe instrument in the range of 30-500 °C under a nitrogen flow at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE XRD instrument using Cu Kα radiation. The UV-vis spectra were measured on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV/vis/NIR spectrometer. Mass spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu GC-MS QP2010 plus instrument. The humid environment was controlled by an Espec Corp. SH-221 humidity control oven. The impedance measurements were carried out under multiple different environmental conditions by the conventional quasi-four-probe method, using gold paste and gold wires (50 μm diameter) with a Solartron SI 1260 Impedance/Gain-Phase Analyzer and 1296 Dielectric Interface in the frequency range of 1 MHz to 0.1 Hz.

elements.content: Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (596 mg, 2 mmol) and bamdpH4 (590 mg, 2 mmol) were added to 22 mL of distilled water and 28 mL of HCONH2. The pH value was adjusted to 3.55 with 0.5 M NaOH. Then the mixture was transferred to a 180 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 140 °C for 1.5 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals were obtained. The crystals were washed with distilled water and dried in air. Yield: 311.7 mg (18.6% based on Co). The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C19H41Co2N5O16P4: C, 27.25; H, 4.94; N, 8.36. Found: C, 27.11; H, 5.17; N, 8.44.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1)

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (596 mg, 2 mmol) and bamdpH4 (590 mg, 2 mmol) were added to 22 mL of distilled water and 28 mL of HCONH2. The pH value was adjusted to 3.55 with 0.5 M NaOH. Then the mixture was transferred to a 180 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 140 °C for 1.5 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals were obtained. The crystals were washed with distilled water and dried in air. Yield: 311.7 mg (18.6% based on Co). The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C19H41Co2N5O16P4: C, 27.25; H, 4.94; N, 8.36. Found: C, 27.11; H, 5.17; N, 8.44.

elements.content: Compound 2 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 1 at 60 °C and 95% RH for 2 days. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C9H21CoNO10P2: C, 25.48; H, 4.99; N, 3.30. Found: C, 25.47; H, 4.94; N, 3.89.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2)

Compound 2 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 1 at 60 °C and 95% RH for 2 days. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C9H21CoNO10P2: C, 25.48; H, 4.99; N, 3.30. Found: C, 25.47; H, 4.94; N, 3.89.

elements.content: Compound 3 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 2 at 25 °C and <10% RH for 1 day. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C18H36Co2N2O17P4: C, 27.22; H, 4.57; N, 3.53. Found: C, 27.10; H, 4.57; N, 4.27.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (3)

Compound 3 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 2 at 25 °C and <10% RH for 1 day. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C18H36Co2N2O17P4: C, 27.22; H, 4.57; N, 3.53. Found: C, 27.10; H, 4.57; N, 4.27.

elements.content: Single crystals of the three compounds were selected for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector face plate. Absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXTL. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. The crystallographic data of compounds 1–3 are given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in –, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals of the three compounds were selected for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector face plate. Absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXTL. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. The crystallographic data of compounds 1-3 are given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in  -, respectively.

The compound (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)­(H2O)2] (1) was synthesized by solvothermal treatment of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O and bamdpH4 in H2O and HCONH2. Single-crystal structural determination reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (). Its asymmetric unit consists of one CoII, one bamdpH3–, one and a half NH4 +, a half HCOO–, and one coordination water molecule (a). The NH4 + and HCOO– was produced in situ due to the hydrolysis of HCONH2 in acidic solution (pH 3.5–3.6). As shown in a, the CoII has a distorted-octahedral geometry surrounded by three oxygen atoms (O2, O4, O5) and one nitrogen atom (N1) from the phosphonate ligand, one water molecule (O1W), and one oxygen atom (O7) from HCOO–. The Co–O­(N) bond lengths fall in the range of 2.082(2)–2.255(2) Å, in agreement with those found in the other cobalt phosphonates.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures and SC-SC Transformation

The compound (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1) was synthesized by solvothermal treatment of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and bamdpH4 in H2O and HCONH2. Single-crystal structural determination reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (). Its asymmetric unit consists of one CoII, one bamdpH3-, one and a half NH4 +, a half HCOO-, and one coordination water molecule (a). The NH4 + and HCOO- was produced in situ due to the hydrolysis of HCONH2 in acidic solution (pH 3.5-3.6). As shown in a, the CoII has a distorted-octahedral geometry surrounded by three oxygen atoms (O2, O4, O5) and one nitrogen atom (N1) from the phosphonate ligand, one water molecule (O1W), and one oxygen atom (O7) from HCOO-. The Co-O(N) bond lengths fall in the range of 2.082(2)-2.255(2) Å, in agreement with those found in the other cobalt phosphonates.

elements.content: (a) Building unit with atomic labeling scheme (30% probability) for structure 1. Symmetry code A: x, y – 1, z. (b) Ladderlike chain in compound 1. (c) Packing diagram of structure 1 viewed along the b axis. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Building unit with atomic labeling scheme (30% probability) for structure 1. Symmetry code A: x, y - 1, z. (b) Ladderlike chain in compound 1. (c) Packing diagram of structure 1 viewed along the b axis. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: bamdpH3– serves as a tetradentate ligand by using the amino nitrogen (N1) and three of its six phosphonate oxygen atoms (O2, O4, O5). The remaining three phosphonate oxygen atoms are either protonated (O6) or pendant (O1, O3). It chelates and bridges the equivalent cobalt­(II) ions, forming an infinite chain of {Co­(bamdpH)­(H2O)} n running along the b axis (b). The nearest Co···Co distance over the O–P–O bridge is 6.358(1) Å. The adjacent {Co­(bamdpH)­(H2O)} n chains are pillared by the HCOO– bridges via O7 atoms, leading to a ladderlike double-chain structure (b). The Co···Co distance over the HCOO– bridge is 6.019(1) Å. Moderately strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are observed between the neighboring double chains: e.g. 2.798(1) Å for d O1W–O1, 2.607(1) Å for d O6–O1, and 2.717(1) Å for d O1W–O3, leading to a supramolecular layer in the bc plane with one-dimensional channels generated along the c axis. The channels are hydrophilic, occupied by NH4 + ions with extensive hydrogen bonds (d O2–N3 = 2.838(1) Å, d O3–N3 = 2.682(1) Å, d O7–N2 = 2.878(1) Å) (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The van der Waals and weak hydrogen bond interactions are dominant between the supramolecular layers (c).
elements.clean_text: bamdpH3- serves as a tetradentate ligand by using the amino nitrogen (N1) and three of its six phosphonate oxygen atoms (O2, O4, O5). The remaining three phosphonate oxygen atoms are either protonated (O6) or pendant (O1, O3). It chelates and bridges the equivalent cobalt(II) ions, forming an infinite chain of {Co(bamdpH)(H2O)} n  running along the b axis (b). The nearest Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance over the O-P-O bridge is 6.358(1) Å. The adjacent {Co(bamdpH)(H2O)} n  chains are pillared by the HCOO- bridges via O7 atoms, leading to a ladderlike double-chain structure (b). The Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance over the HCOO- bridge is 6.019(1) Å. Moderately strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are observed between the neighboring double chains: e.g. 2.798(1) Å for d O1W-O1, 2.607(1) Å for d O6-O1, and 2.717(1) Å for d O1W-O3, leading to a supramolecular layer in the bc plane with one-dimensional channels generated along the c axis. The channels are hydrophilic, occupied by NH4 + ions with extensive hydrogen bonds (d O2-N3 = 2.838(1) Å, d O3-N3 = 2.682(1) Å, d O7-N2 = 2.878(1) Å) (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The van der Waals and weak hydrogen bond interactions are dominant between the supramolecular layers (c).

elements.content: Thermal analysis under a nitrogen gas flow reveals that compound 1 is stable up to ca. 160 °C (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The weight loss between 160 and 233 °C is 15.8%, consistent with the removal of one HCOOH, three NH3, and two H2O molecules (calcd 15.9%). The in situ IR spectra measurements suggest that compound 1 is stable below 180 °C when the environment is dry (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Thermal analysis under a nitrogen gas flow reveals that compound 1 is stable up to ca. 160 °C (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The weight loss between 160 and 233 °C is 15.8%, consistent with the removal of one HCOOH, three NH3, and two H2O molecules (calcd 15.9%). The in situ IR spectra measurements suggest that compound 1 is stable below 180 °C when the environment is dry (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: However, upon exposure to 95% RH at 60 °C for 1 day, compound 1 experiences a SC-SC structural transformation, forming the neutral compound [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·2H2O (2) (). Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (). Unlike compound 1, the asymmetric unit of 2 only contains one CoII, one bamdpH2 2–, and four water molecules (a). Subsequently, compound 2 shows a single-chain structure in which the cobalt atoms are cross-linked by the O–P–O bridges. The Co···Co distance over the O–P–O unit within the chain is 6.274(2) Å, slightly shorter than that in compound 1 (6.358(1) Å). The {Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2} n chain in 2 is similar to that in 1 except that one coordination site of cobalt occupied by an oxygen atom from HCOO– is now replaced by a water molecule and the phosphonate ligand is doubly protonated in 2. The adjacent chains are hydrogen-bonded to each other (d O2W–O3 = 2.787(1) Å, d O6–O1 = 2.573(1) Å, d O1W–O2 = 2.727(1) Å), forming a supramolecular double-chain structure (b and Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). The lattice water molecules reside in the cavities of the double chain.
elements.clean_text: However, upon exposure to 95% RH at 60 °C for 1 day, compound 1 experiences a SC-SC structural transformation, forming the neutral compound [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2) (). Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (). Unlike compound 1, the asymmetric unit of 2 only contains one CoII, one bamdpH2 2-, and four water molecules (a). Subsequently, compound 2 shows a single-chain structure in which the cobalt atoms are cross-linked by the O-P-O bridges. The Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance over the O-P-O unit within the chain is 6.274(2) Å, slightly shorter than that in compound 1 (6.358(1) Å). The {Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2} n  chain in 2 is similar to that in 1 except that one coordination site of cobalt occupied by an oxygen atom from HCOO- is now replaced by a water molecule and the phosphonate ligand is doubly protonated in 2. The adjacent chains are hydrogen-bonded to each other (d O2W-O3 = 2.787(1) Å, d O6-O1 = 2.573(1) Å, d O1W-O2 = 2.727(1) Å), forming a supramolecular double-chain structure (b and Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). The lattice water molecules reside in the cavities of the double chain.

elements.content: SC-SC-SC transformation of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  SC-SC-SC transformation of compound 1.

elements.content: (a) Building unit with atomic labeling scheme (30% probability) for structure 2. Symmetry code A: x, y + 1, z. (b) Packing diagram of structure 2 viewed along the b axis. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Building unit with atomic labeling scheme (30% probability) for structure 2. Symmetry code A: x, y + 1, z. (b) Packing diagram of structure 2 viewed along the b axis. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: One lattice water molecule in compound 2 can be further removed in a SC-SC manner by keeping it under dry conditions (25 °C, <10% RH) for several hours, resulting in the compound [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·H2O (3) (). Compound 3 also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (). A single-chain structure is again observed with the nearest Co···Co distance of 6.257(2) Å. One of the phosphonate groups (P1) in 3 is disordered over two sites (a). The shortest Co···Co distance between the adjacent chains increases to 5.770(1) Å, slightly larger than that in compound 2 (5.584(1) Å). The larger distance in 3 is attributed to the sliding of the chain in the ac plane. The transformation between 2 and 3 is reversible, depending on the humidity.
elements.clean_text: One lattice water molecule in compound 2 can be further removed in a SC-SC manner by keeping it under dry conditions (25 °C, <10% RH) for several hours, resulting in the compound [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (3) (). Compound 3 also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (). A single-chain structure is again observed with the nearest Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance of 6.257(2) Å. One of the phosphonate groups (P1) in 3 is disordered over two sites (a). The shortest Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance between the adjacent chains increases to 5.770(1) Å, slightly larger than that in compound 2 (5.584(1) Å). The larger distance in 3 is attributed to the sliding of the chain in the ac plane. The transformation between 2 and 3 is reversible, depending on the humidity.

elements.content: It is very interesting to find that the coordinated HCOO– and NH4 + counterions in compound 1 are completely released at 60 °C and 95% RH, although the compound can be maintained up to 180 °C in N2. In order to detect the possible reaction products of the material under high humidity, mass spectra (MS) were used. shows the MS signals of the air and gas phase of compound 1 after it was kept at 80 °C and 95% RH for 3 h. In comparison with those of the air, the signals at m/z 29 and 44 are significantly enhanced, and new signals at m/z 45 and 46 appear. These signals are in agreement with the m/z values for HCO+, OCO+, HCOO+, and HCOOH+ species. Unfortunately, the signals related to NH3 cannot be identified by mass spectra, because they are overlapped by those of H2O. By using an indophenol assay procedure, the number of released NH3 groups is estimated to be 2.52 per formula of 1 (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information), which agrees with the experimental value of 3.00 for the fresh 1. Therefore, the humidity-induced hydrolysis process of compound 1 can be expressed by the equation ( NH 4 ) 3 [ Co 2 ( bamdpH ) 2 ( HCOO ) ( H 2 O ) 2 ] 1 + 6 H 2 O → 2 [ Co ( bamdpH 2 ) ( H 2 O ) 2 ] · 2 H 2 O 2 + 3 NH 3 + HCOOH
elements.clean_text:
Dynamics of the Transformation from 1 to 2 

It is very interesting to find that the coordinated HCOO- and NH4 + counterions in compound 1 are completely released at 60 °C and 95% RH, although the compound can be maintained up to 180 °C in N2. In order to detect the possible reaction products of the material under high humidity, mass spectra (MS) were used.  shows the MS signals of the air and gas phase of compound 1 after it was kept at 80 °C and 95% RH for 3 h. In comparison with those of the air, the signals at m/z 29 and 44 are significantly enhanced, and new signals at m/z 45 and 46 appear. These signals are in agreement with the m/z values for HCO+, OCO+, HCOO+, and HCOOH+ species. Unfortunately, the signals related to NH3 cannot be identified by mass spectra, because they are overlapped by those of H2O. By using an indophenol assay procedure, the number of released NH3 groups is estimated to be 2.52 per formula of 1 (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information), which agrees with the experimental value of 3.00 for the fresh 1. Therefore, the humidity-induced hydrolysis process of compound 1 can be expressed by the equation         (   NH   4   )   3    [   Co   2     ( bamdpH )   2    ( HCOO )    (   H   2   O )   2   ]    1   + 6   H   2   O → 2    [ Co  (   bamdpH   2   )    (   H   2   O )   2   ]  ⋅ 2   H   2   O   2   + 3   NH   3   + HCOOH

elements.content: Mass spectra for the air (top) and the gas phase of compound 1 after it was kept at 80 °C and 95% RH for 3 h (bottom).
elements.clean_text: 5  Mass spectra for the air (top) and the gas phase of compound 1 after it was kept at 80 °C and 95% RH for 3 h (bottom).

elements.content: Noting that the HCOO– contains a CO group, the IR spectra can be used to monitor the transformation from 1 to 2 simply by comparing the intensities of νCO. As shown in a, the vibration band of νCO at 1592 cm–1 almost disappears after 20 min of treatment of compound 1 at 60 °C and 95% RH. When the temperature is reduced to 40 °C, it takes about 12 h to complete the hydrolysis (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). In contrast, the spectrum remains almost unchanged after the sample is kept at 35 °C and 95% RH for 12 h. The results suggest that the transformation is also temperature dependent and can be detected easily above 35 °C.
elements.clean_text: Noting that the HCOO- contains a CO group, the IR spectra can be used to monitor the transformation from 1 to 2 simply by comparing the intensities of νCO. As shown in a, the vibration band of νCO at 1592 cm-1 almost disappears after 20 min of treatment of compound 1 at 60 °C and 95% RH. When the temperature is reduced to 40 °C, it takes about 12 h to complete the hydrolysis (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). In contrast, the spectrum remains almost unchanged after the sample is kept at 35 °C and 95% RH for 12 h. The results suggest that the transformation is also temperature dependent and can be detected easily above 35 °C.

elements.content: (a) IR spectra of compound 1 treated at 60 °C and 95% RH. (b) S 739/S 1592 vs time and (c) ln k vs T –1 plots of compound 1 treated at 95% RH at different temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) IR spectra of compound 1 treated at 60 °C and 95% RH. (b) S 739/S 1592 vs time and (c) ln k vs T -1 plots of compound 1 treated at 95% RH at different temperatures.

elements.content: To investigate the dynamics of hydrolysis in 1, we measured the IR spectra of compound 1 treated in the temperature range of 48–60 °C and 95% RH for different periods of time (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). The band at 739 cm–1 which corresponds to the characteristic vibration of monosubstituted phenyl was selected as the reference band. This band is thought to be unchanged before and after structural transformation. Thus, the unreleased HCOO– should be proportional to the ratio of the band areas of S 1592/S 739. We assume that the transformation process is of second order following : S 739 S 1592 = − k t where S 1592 and S 739 correspond to the areas of the bands at time t. The rate constants (k) can be obtained as 0.016, 0.054, 0.086, and 0.16 min–1 at temperatures of 48, 52, 56, and 60 °C, respectively (b). The activation energy (E a) of the transformation process can be derived according to the Arrhenius law: ln k = ln k 0 – E a/RT, which is estimated as 39.9 ± 5.8 kcal/mol (c).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the dynamics of hydrolysis in 1, we measured the IR spectra of compound 1 treated in the temperature range of 48-60 °C and 95% RH for different periods of time (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). The band at 739 cm-1 which corresponds to the characteristic vibration of monosubstituted phenyl was selected as the reference band. This band is thought to be unchanged before and after structural transformation. Thus, the unreleased HCOO- should be proportional to the ratio of the band areas of S 1592/S 739. We assume that the transformation process is of second order following : 1        S   739       S   1592     = - k t   where S 1592 and S 739 correspond to the areas of the bands at time t. The rate constants (k) can be obtained as 0.016, 0.054, 0.086, and 0.16 min-1 at temperatures of 48, 52, 56, and 60 °C, respectively (b). The activation energy (E a) of the transformation process can be derived according to the Arrhenius law: ln k = ln k 0 - E a/RT, which is estimated as 39.9 ± 5.8 kcal/mol (c).

elements.content: As described above, the structural transformation from compound 1 to 2 accompanies a change in the hydrogen-bonding networks of the two structures. Such a change can be reflected in their proton conductivities. Thus, the proton conductivities of compound 1 were measured by ac impedance spectroscopy using a compressed pellet with two gold electrodes attached to the surface (Figures S11 and S12 in the Supporting Information). The pellet was kept for ca. 12 h under each set of conditions before the measurements. At 25 °C and 45% RH, the conductivity of compound 1 is 2.6 × 10–12 S/cm. The value increases with increased humidity, indicating the importance of water for the transport of H+ (Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). At 25 °C and 95% RH, the conductivity reaches 8.0 × 10–6 S/cm. The temperature dependence of the conductivity was measured from 20 to 55 °C at 95% RH (a,b). In the range of 20–30 °C, the Arrhenius fit of the data results in an activation energy (E a LT) of 0.69 eV (d). However, above 35 °C the plot shows a deviation from the line, which can be attributed to the occurrence of a phase transition from compound 1 to 2. A linear fit of the data in the temperature range 40–55 °C gives an activation energy (E a HT) of 1.90 eV. The higher value of E a HT in comparison with E a LT could be due to the involvement of large species in the hydrogen-bonding network after hydrolysis, such as HCOOH and NH4 +. The phase transition temperature, defined by the crossover of two lines, is 38 °C, which is consistent with the IR results.
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conductive Properties

As described above, the structural transformation from compound 1 to 2 accompanies a change in the hydrogen-bonding networks of the two structures. Such a change can be reflected in their proton conductivities. Thus, the proton conductivities of compound 1 were measured by ac impedance spectroscopy using a compressed pellet with two gold electrodes attached to the surface (Figures S11 and S12 in the Supporting Information). The pellet was kept for ca. 12 h under each set of conditions before the measurements. At 25 °C and 45% RH, the conductivity of compound 1 is 2.6 × 10-12 S/cm. The value increases with increased humidity, indicating the importance of water for the transport of H+ (Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). At 25 °C and 95% RH, the conductivity reaches 8.0 × 10-6 S/cm. The temperature dependence of the conductivity was measured from 20 to 55 °C at 95% RH (a,b). In the range of 20-30 °C, the Arrhenius fit of the data results in an activation energy (E a LT) of 0.69 eV (d). However, above 35 °C the plot shows a deviation from the line, which can be attributed to the occurrence of a phase transition from compound 1 to 2. A linear fit of the data in the temperature range 40-55 °C gives an activation energy (E a HT) of 1.90 eV. The higher value of E a HT in comparison with E a LT could be due to the involvement of large species in the hydrogen-bonding network after hydrolysis, such as HCOOH and NH4 +. The phase transition temperature, defined by the crossover of two lines, is 38 °C, which is consistent with the IR results.

elements.content: –Z″ vs Z′ plots of compound 1 measured at 95% RH in the heating (a, b) and cooling (c) processes. (d) ln­(kT) vs T –1 plots of compound 1. The solid lines represent the best fits according to the Arrhenius law.
elements.clean_text: 7  -Z" vs Z' plots of compound 1 measured at 95% RH in the heating (a, b) and cooling (c) processes. (d) ln(kT) vs T -1 plots of compound 1. The solid lines represent the best fits according to the Arrhenius law.

elements.content: For a comparison, the proton conductivity of compound 2 was also measured (Figures S14–S17 in the Supporting Information). Its conductivity again shows humidity dependence, increasing from 7.3 × 10–10 S/cm at 25 °C and 45% RH to 1.9 × 10–6 S/cm at 95% RH. Obviously, compound 2 shows lower conductivities than 1 over the whole temperature range at 95% RH. The activation energy, obtained by an Arrhenius fit of the data between 20 and 50 °C, is 0.75 eV for 2 (Figure S18 in the Supporting Information). The relatively large activation energies in the two compounds are indicative of a vehicle mechanism.
elements.clean_text: For a comparison, the proton conductivity of compound 2 was also measured (Figures S14-S17 in the Supporting Information). Its conductivity again shows humidity dependence, increasing from 7.3 × 10-10 S/cm at 25 °C and 45% RH to 1.9 × 10-6 S/cm at 95% RH. Obviously, compound 2 shows lower conductivities than 1 over the whole temperature range at 95% RH. The activation energy, obtained by an Arrhenius fit of the data between 20 and 50 °C, is 0.75 eV for 2 (Figure S18 in the Supporting Information). The relatively large activation energies in the two compounds are indicative of a vehicle mechanism.

elements.content: We have demonstrated that multiple-step humidity-induced SC-SC transformations can be achieved in a cobalt phosphonate with a double-chain structure: namely, (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)­(H2O)2] (1). Under high humidity (95% RH) and at 60 °C, the hydrolysis of the bridging ligand of HCOO– occurs, leading to a second phase, [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·2H2O (2). When the humidity is reduced to below 10% RH, one lattice water in compound 2 is released, forming a third phase, [Co­(bamdpH2)­(H2O)2]·H2O (3). Interestingly, the structural transformation from compound 1 to 2 can be monitored by IR and proton conductivity measurements. The activation energy (E a) of the transformation process on the basis of the IR data is estimated as 39.9 ± 5.8 kcal/mol.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have demonstrated that multiple-step humidity-induced SC-SC transformations can be achieved in a cobalt phosphonate with a double-chain structure: namely, (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1). Under high humidity (95% RH) and at 60 °C, the hydrolysis of the bridging ligand of HCOO- occurs, leading to a second phase, [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2). When the humidity is reduced to below 10% RH, one lattice water in compound 2 is released, forming a third phase, [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (3). Interestingly, the structural transformation from compound 1 to 2 can be monitored by IR and proton conductivity measurements. The activation energy (E a) of the transformation process on the basis of the IR data is estimated as 39.9 ± 5.8 kcal/mol.

cln_elements.content:
Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (596 mg, 2 mmol) and bamdpH4 (590 mg, 2 mmol) were added to 22 mL of distilled water and 28 mL of HCONH2. The pH value was adjusted to 3.55 with 0.5 M NaOH. Then the mixture was transferred to a 180 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 140 °C for 1.5 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals were obtained. The crystals were washed with distilled water and dried in air. Yield: 311.7 mg (18.6% based on Co). The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C19H41Co2N5O16P4: C, 27.25; H, 4.94; N, 8.36. Found: C, 27.11; H, 5.17; N, 8.44.

Synthesis of [Co­(bamdpH<sub>2</sub>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 1 at 60 °C and 95% RH for 2 days. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C9H21CoNO10P2: C, 25.48; H, 4.99; N, 3.30. Found: C, 25.47; H, 4.94; N, 3.89.

Synthesis of [Co­(bamdpH<sub>2</sub>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 2 at 25 °C and <10% RH for 1 day. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C18H36Co2N2O17P4: C, 27.22; H, 4.57; N, 3.53. Found: C, 27.10; H, 4.57; N, 4.27.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (NH4)3[Co2(bamdpH)2(HCOO)(H2O)2] (1)

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (596 mg, 2 mmol) and bamdpH4 (590 mg, 2 mmol) were added to 22 mL of distilled water and 28 mL of HCONH2. The pH value was adjusted to 3.55 with 0.5 M NaOH. Then the mixture was transferred to a 180 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 140 °C for 1.5 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals were obtained. The crystals were washed with distilled water and dried in air. Yield: 311.7 mg (18.6% based on Co). The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C19H41Co2N5O16P4: C, 27.25; H, 4.94; N, 8.36. Found: C, 27.11; H, 5.17; N, 8.44.

Synthesis of [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2)

Compound 2 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 1 at 60 °C and 95% RH for 2 days. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C9H21CoNO10P2: C, 25.48; H, 4.99; N, 3.30. Found: C, 25.47; H, 4.94; N, 3.89.

Synthesis of [Co(bamdpH2)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (3)

Compound 3 was obtained by keeping the crystals of compound 2 at 25 °C and <10% RH for 1 day. The purity of the phase was confirmed by a PXRD pattern (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C18H36Co2N2O17P4: C, 27.22; H, 4.57; N, 3.53. Found: C, 27.10; H, 4.57; N, 4.27.

cln_elements.content: Thermal analysis under a nitrogen gas flow reveals that compound 1 is stable up to ca. 160 °C (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The weight loss between 160 and 233 °C is 15.8%, consistent with the removal of one HCOOH, three NH3, and two H2O molecules (calcd 15.9%). The in situ IR spectra measurements suggest that compound 1 is stable below 180 °C when the environment is dry (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information).

metadata.title:
Multiple-Step Humidity-Induced Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal
Transformations of a Cobalt Phosphonate: Structural and Proton Conductivity Studies
